messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Circuits and Backdoors: Five Shades of the SETH

Paper Abstract: Abstract The SETH is a hypothesis of fundamental importance to (fine-grained) parameterized complexity theory and many important tight lower bounds are based on it. This situation is somewhat problematic, because the validity of the SETH is not universally believed and because in some senses the SETH seems to be ‚Äútoo strong‚Äù a hypothesis for the considered lower bounds. Motivated by this, we consider a number of reasonable weakenings of the SETH that render it more plausible, with sources ranging from circuit complexity, to backdoors for SAT-solving, to graph width parameters, to weighted satisfiability problems. Despite the diversity of the different formulations, we are able to uncover several non-obvious connections using tools from classical complexity theory. This leads us to a hierarchy of five main equivalence classes of hypotheses, with some of the highlights being the following: 1. We show that beating brute force search for SAT parameterized by a modulator to a graph of bounded pathwidth, or bounded treewidth, or logarithmic tree-depth, is actually the same question, despite the structural differences between these parameters. In fact, we show that beating brute force for any of these parameters is possible if and only if one can beat brute force for circuits of depth Œµ‚ÄãnùúÄùëõ\varepsilon n (a weaker version of the so-called NC-SETH). We also show that all these questions are equivalent to the existence of an n(1‚àíŒµ)‚Äãksuperscriptùëõ1ùúÄùëòn^{(1-\varepsilon)k} algorithm for the weighted satisfiability problem associated with W[SAT]. A main tool we use here is Barrington‚Äôs theorem. 2. On the other hand, modulators to logarithmic pathwidth seem to belong to a different class. We show that beating brute force for this parameter is equivalent to beating brute force for SAT when given a strong 2-SAT backdoor. To prove this we rely on ideas from the classical Immerman‚ÄìSzelepcs√©nyi theorem. 3. Identifying an even harder class of problems, we show that beating brute force for SAT given a strong Horn backdoor is equivalent to the SETH for general circuits (without depth restrictions) and to beating brute force for the weighted satisfiability problem of the class W[P]. 4. Going in the other direction, we revisit recent work of Esmer, Focke, Marx, and Rzazewski (ICALP ‚Äô24), and uncover some nuances in their lower bounds. In particular, we show that beating brute force for SAT parameterized by a modulator to constant tree-depth is equivalent to falsifying the standard form of the SETH. This allows us to show that their lower bound for qùëûq-Coloring (for parameter (œÉ,Œ¥)ùúéùõø(\sigma,\delta)-hub) is actually not just an implication, but a reformulation of the SETH. On the other hand, we show that their lower bound for Max-Cut for the same parameter is equivalent to the maximization version of the SETH, which at the moment appears to be a weaker hypothesis. For each of these classes we give at least one (non-SAT) problem which is equivalent to the class as a characteristic example application. Our work is a step towards a more nuanced meta-complexity theory where we advance from proving one-way implications of the SETH, to establishing a classification of interesting questions into equivalence classes. A somewhat unusual aspect is that our classification cuts across traditional time complexity classes, as we are often able to establish equivalences between lower bounds for FPT problems (of the form (c‚àíŒµ)k‚ÄãnO‚Äã(1)superscriptùëêùúÄùëòsuperscriptùëõùëÇ1(c-\varepsilon)^{k}n^{O(1)}) and non-FPT problems (of the form n(1‚àíŒµ)‚Äãksuperscriptùëõ1ùúÄùëòn^{(1-\varepsilon)k}).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Tighter connections between formula-sat and shaving logs",
        "Seth-based lower bounds for subset sum and bicriteria path",
        "Simulating branching programs with edit distance and friends: or: a polylog shaved is a lower bound made",
        "Matching triangles and basing hardness on an extremely popular conjecture",
        "Bounded-width polynomial-size branching programs recognize exactly those languages in NC1",
        "Tight bounds for connectivity problems parameterized by cutwidth",
        "Size-depth tradeoffs for boolean fomulae",
        "Optimal dynamic program for r-domination problems over tree decompositions",
        "Fine-grained complexity meets IP = PSPACE",
        "Tight conditional lower bounds for counting perfect matchings on graphs of bounded treewidth, cliquewidth, and genus",
        "On problems as hard as CNF-SAT",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "New algorithms for mixed dominating set",
        "Upper dominating set: Tight algorithms for pathwidth and sub-exponential approximation",
        "Fundamental problems on bounded-treewidth graphs: The real source of hardness",
        "Tight complexity bounds for counting generalized dominating sets in bounded-treewidth graphs",
        "Counting list homomorphisms from graphs of bounded treewidth: tight complexity bounds",
        "The fine-grained complexity of graph homomorphism parameterized by clique-width",
        "Backdoors to satisfaction",
        "Strong backdoors to bounded treewidth SAT",
        "Parameterized orientable deletion",
        "Tight algorithms for connectivity problems parameterized by clique-width",
        "Tight algorithms for connectivity problems parameterized by modular-treewidth",
        "Nondeterministic space is closed under complementation",
        "On the complexity of k-sat",
        "On the equivalence among problems of bounded width",
        "Fine-grained parameterized complexity analysis of graph coloring problems",
        "Structural parameters, tight bounds, and approximation for (k, r)-center",
        "Structurally parameterized d-scattered set",
        "Finer tight bounds for coloring on clique-width",
        "The primal pathwidth SETH",
        "Structural parameterizations for two bounded degree problems revisited",
        "Known algorithms on graphs of bounded treewidth are probably optimal",
        "Twelve years of QBF evaluations: QSAT is pspace-hard and it shows",
        "Degrees and gaps: Tight complexity results of general factor problems parameterized by treewidth and cutwidth",
        "The parameterized complexity of editing graphs for bounded degeneracy",
        "Detecting backdoor sets with respect to horn and binary clauses",
        "Fine-grained complexity of the graph homomorphism problem for bounded-treewidth graphs",
        "Computational complexity",
        "On the possibility of faster SAT algorithms",
        "Why is it hard to beat O(n22{}^{\\mbox{2}}) for longest common weakly increasing subsequence?",
        "Backdoor sets for DLL subsolvers",
        "Some estimated likelihoods for computational complexity",
        "Strong ETH breaks with merlin and arthur: Short non-interactive proofs of batch evaluation",
        "Backdoors to typical case complexity"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Circuits and Backdoors: Five Shades of the SETH, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
